issues.title: User friends
issues.body:
Hy guys

I didn't find (looking at the code and ate the docs) if it's possible to retrieve user's friends
http://developer.runkeeper.com/healthgraph/friends

If no, I can implement it (I just don't want to do an already exiting function).

issues.title: Broken accept header test
issues.body: Currently one of the test for this gem does not pass.  The accept headers expected don't account for an additional header that is sent back from the health graph.

commits.message:
Replace jeweler with bundler for building/releasing gem

In order to fix an issue with a circular dependency, this commit removes
jeweler from the project's development dependencies and instead uses the
built in facilities in bundler for gem building and releasing. This
commit also fixes a broken spec and adds a rake task for running specs.

Add build status badge

This commit adds a build status badge on the project readme.

Add travis ci file

This commit adds a travis ci file for building and running tests.

issue_comments.body: @jgadbois This is probably not the most correct way to resolve the dependency issue. The dependencies should in fact live in the gemspec. I can see if fresh eyes can solve the issue though :smile:
@jgadbois Sounds like jeweler should be ripped out and plain ol' bundler will do the trick here.

@jgadbois I'm working on resolving this same issue by pulling out jeweler and just using bundler. Once I've got it working locally, I will push my work up to GitHub and make a pull request on this repo. Although I haven't seen any activity on this repository in a long time so a proper fork may be in order.
@jgadbois I've opened [a new pull request](https://github.com/kennyma/health_graph/pull/20) that should fix the circular dependency. It also fixes a broken spec and allows for running specs via rake.

Been two years that this has been opened. I don't think this is going to be merged.... :sob:

commits.message:
Fix tests for Ruby 1.8.7.

The newline between the object and method doesn't work in Ruby 1.8.
Otherwise, the gem already works fine. So I figure this should be
fixed.

Add Jeweler development dependency.

It's only used for generating the gemspec, but the Rakefile requires
it, and this seems less surprising than rescuing the LoadError.

Fix removed Faraday JSON middleware.

The JSON request middleware is no longer included with Faraday. This
seems to have already been partially fixed, since FaradayMiddleware
was already a dependency.

The tests are now passing on Ruby 1.9.

Use SimpleCov instead of RCov.

RCov doesn't work on Ruby 1.9. SimpleCov does.

Remove rubygems and bundler boilerplate.

These are both environmental concerns, and do not belong in library
code. And RubyGems is part of the 1.9 stdlib, so this isn't necessary.

Remove duplicate dependencies from Gemfile.

Since we're using Jeweler to generate the gemspec, the dependencies
belong in the Rakefile.

This was already patched by @aub, but his pull request hasn't been
accepted yet. I'm including it here to keep things simple.

Remove Gemfile.lock.

This file should not be checked into version control when developing
gems, because it imposes very specific dependencies on app authors
attempting to use it.

See: http://yehudakatz.com/2010/12/16/clarifying-the-roles-of-the-gemspec-and-gemfile/

pull_requests.title: Return DateTime objects instead of strings from temporal methods
pull_requests.body:
This is a fairly major change, which breaks backwards compatibility (albeit in an easily-fixable way). So if it seems useful, please check it carefully before merging.

Currently, the time-related accessors like `FitnessActivitiesFeed::Item#start_time` return strings straight from RunKeeper. They look something like `"Thu, 15 Sep 2011 13:28:59"`. This is fine for displaying as-is, but not a lot of use for anything else. This patch intercepts the values before they're stored (in the `Model#populate_from_hash!` method), and coerces them into `DateTime` objects.

The implementation is a little more complex than it _needs_ to be, because I've tried to model it after [`Hashie::Extensions::Coercion`](https://github.com/intridea/hashie/blob/master/lib/hashie/extensions/coercion.rb), so we can easily replace this minimal solution with theirs, once a stable release is available. Faraday already uses Hashie, so it isn't a new dependency.

Coercion looks like (from `weight_feed.rb`):

``` ruby
hash_attr_accessor :timestamp, :weight, :uri # etc
coerce_key :timestamp, HealthGraph::DateTime
```

The `HealthGraph::DateTime` class is just a wrapper around `::DateTime` which knows how to parse RunKeeper-style timestamps. Any class with a `coerce` method can be used.

pull_requests.title: Add pagination to acitities feed
pull_requests.body:
This adds `:next_page` and `:previous_page` methods to `FitnessActitiesFeed`, which return new instances of the same class. The existing `:next` and `:previous` accessors work as before, although they're not very useful now that pagination is available.

For example, to fetch every item ever posted:
(This would obviously be a very bad idea in production)

``` ruby
feed = @user.fitness_activities
items = []

while feed
  items += feed.items
  feed = feed.next_page
end
```

This involved a minor refactoring of the test fixtures. Hope you don't mind.

/cc @andrewpbrett

pull_requests.title: rubocop --auto-correct
pull_requests.body: Adds and run `rubocop --autocorrect` to automatically fix mainly style offenses (extra whitespace, missing newlines, pre-Ruby 1.9 hash syntax, single quotes etc)

issue_comments.body: I believe the gem requires ruby 1.8.7.  But I did not actually write the gem, so I can not confirm.
Same problem for me, tested with 1.8.7 and 1.9.3.

I know this is an old issue but I'm experiencing the same issue trying to install health_plan using ruby 2.1.3

Any suggestions on how to address this?
@endoze I'm attempting to use this branch in my Gemfile and still getting the circular dependency.  Any ideas?
@endoze thanks would love to get this solved.  I did see several other gems with jeweler issues that were trying to fix the same way
Anyway you could update this branch and i could test in my Gemfile pulling from the branch?
@endoze this worked for me!  Having our other dev who initially encountered the problem try as well.  Thanks!
I've just run into the same problem as well
+1, fixes an infinite recursion error in new versions of bundler
I resolved it on my branch with https://github.com/dsjoerg/health_graph/commit/9f4bc38998cc7b557992d18e04a6347503665cc9
